prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request the TDM spectral setup since we are interested in the continuum flux.

Here the requested angular resolution and largest angular scale are nominal values since the target source is a point source. Any configuration is acceptable, but three visits of our observation would be better to be carried out with the same configuration to avoid the change in the contaminated flux by extended jet and dust.

The continuum flux density is estimated by utilizing the model of the hot and geometrically-thick accretion flow (Mahadevan 1997, ApJ, 477, 585) with basic paramters, the Eddington ratio, black hole mass, and the distance to the source, summarized in Table 1 in the science justification. Because the jet core is indicated to be brighter than the hot and geometrically-thick accretion flow (Doi et al. 2005, MNRAS, 363, 692), the lower limit of the jet core flux density at 100 GHz can be determined to be 22 mJy. We request to detect the source with the signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio better than 20 so that the error due to the S/N does not exceed the flux calibration accuracy of 5% (ref. Proposer's guide).

In this study, we aim to significantly detect ~100 GHz flux variations of compact jet cores with spatial scales within ~0.01 pc in broad-line Seyfert galaxies. Hence, we request three observations in band 3 with time intervals of ~14 days, which corresponds to spatial scales of ~0.01 pc via the light velocity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The origin of relativistic jets is an important subject in astrophysics, and steady jets are known to be accompanied by hot and geometrically-thick accretion flows onto black holes, formed with the low Eddington ratios. Low-luminosity AGNs show the steady jets, composed of jet cores and extended jets with spatial scales of ~0.01 pc and >0.1 pc, respectively. In broad-line Seyfert galaxies with the higher Eddington ratios than low-luminosity AGNs, the extended jets were already found, too. However, their jet core signals have not been detected yet. In this study, we aim to detect, for the first time, 100 GHz signals from jet cores in broad-line Seyfert galaxies, and their varitions on time scales of a few weeks. For this purpose, we propose 3-epoch observations of 6 sources with band 3 of ALMA. The higher Eddington ratios are likely to make their jet cores luminous and compact with scales of <0.01 pc, and the jet core emissions are expected brighter than the extended jets and dusts at 100 GHz. Therefore, the detections of the jet core signals and their variations are feasible enough, with great impacts to understandings of accretion states and jet productions in AGNs.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
Institute of Astronomy, University of Tokyo
School of Science, The University of Tokyo
